B96HBeB6oKdaEdcLkqrgEA.text: Our first visit to this venue was one of the highlights of 2011 so far  so it had a lot to live up to! On our second visit we arrived to find a queue of people waiting to book a table. With no bookings taken over the phone/a first come first serve system, there's always the worry that someone will need to get there quickly from work to secure a table before 9pm. The staff are efficient, fair and friendly though which means it's a less stressful experience to get on that all important list than it might be with the wrong person managing the bookings. The bar was pleasantly busy, with a good rotation of space, as the lucky people (there before you) are called to their table in the main restaurant.The barmen were pretty busy which is why it meant all the more that the gentleman looking after me (I wish I'd got his name) really took some time to help me navigate the wine list. Faced with a selection of grapes that I wasn't familiar with, he allowed me to try one or two wines before settling on a delicious bottle Chianti which stayed delicious through out the next 2 bottles with dinner! We didn't have to wait too long to be seated  about 40mins and we had had some bread and butter to keep us going. The gentleman serving us was the same as before, a lovely fellow with a distinctive moustache and friendly yet professional manner. Generally this is a meat heavy meal. I'm sure they provide well for vegetarians but I have to say I didn't check, as once you start on the menu your mouth starts watering with their descriptions of choices such as Goat, mounds of beef, Steak, Leg of Lamb, chicken etc. One potential downside is that they only plan for a certain amount of dishes each night so when it's gone it's gone. On our second visit we were caught out by this and had to forfeit the lamb (which had been the best dish on our previous visit). For starters the squid was delicious and not too chewy like it can so often be. I enjoyed the lobster soup, although my partner thought is was a bit too this (you cant please everyone!) The best idea for main courses is to team up, as the portions are usually for 2 or moreyou don't need to pick your battle buddy carefully though, as you certainly wont leave hungry. For mains, the Steak/Beef was amazing. Wedges of beef that were both tasty and easy to chew. Honestly, it takes a lot for me to enjoy beef or steak, as I usually find it really chewy, even when others say it's not  I have some theory about evolution here but I'll leave that for another time! The goat was delicious  a meat that a lot of people wouldn't necessarily order but they have no idea what they're missing out on and this was perfectly cooked. My chicken was a little too fruity for me but a sneaky call for some Aioli made all the difference. By the way, The Anchor and Hope don't do sauces  I'm not sure if I agree with that or notThe aioli was definitely a winner though. To full for dessert  do they get that a lot? I'm guessing so. It's not cheap but worth the splurge occasionally with a group of friends who enjoy meat and wine!All round this is a lovely experience, as long as you can get there in good time to book a table before all the best food run out.

rDjLoxy4FbskMCQ7a7IJ6w.text: The Anchor and Hope is a gastropub on The Cut between Waterloo and Southwark underground station. I have now visited twice for dinner and a couple of times for drinks and bar snacks, and I highly recommend that you try it. The pub is split into bar and restaurant sections, both well presented in the mock aged style which is popular at present. A daily changing blackboard menu is on display in the bar, which serves a good range of drinks including excellent lagers and a couple of bitters on tap. It is lucky that the bar section is a good place to relax, as the restaurant does not take bookings so it is a first come first served affair. This is generally no problem, as the staff are very amenable to seating you and it can be quite good fun to share a large table with some randomers. My most recent visit was for a Sunday lunch, when we strolled in quite late (2:30) to be initially told that we had missed the lunchtime service of a set 3 course menu. We had gone barely a couple of steps away from the pub when the chef came running out to catch us and offer just the main course and pudding. This set the tone for the whole meal, as delightfully cooked food was accompanied by superb service. We eventually ended up with some gifts from the kitchen as starters, a main of excellent mutton and an incredible apple tart desert. A special mention really must go to the staff as the service was wonderful. The chef made repeated trips to our table to bring little extras and check we were ok. The waiting staff were attentive, relaxed and , most of all, happy. It makes such a difference when the staff are obviously enjoying themselves, and really added to the whole experience. Well done the Anchor and Hope.

3HQlggIAC0CIxtP4B4RtIg.text: Was happy to get in -- than the food came -- the squid was good the snails just weird.  For entrees the skate was sketchy and the pork dish was OK   Desserts were pretty good.  Service was spotty and the wine list kind of weird and the options are a tiny pour or a half bottle.  They were once on the cutting edge now living off past laurels.. It is a fun place

SxekIfO1EV8w4jL78ynwHg.text: This gastro pub is often packed with a crowd of eager hungry patrons. It gets really busy. 8SRP-xOmbQlzhVwGJfarMQ.text: Had lunch there today. Not so impressed. Meat was chewy and almost raw and, since it was Sunday, had no other choice as it's set menu day! bmy1d85IzjNaZwUovj8NNg.text: My review is based on the food alone. If you factored in the chance of getting a table, then fine, the stars start disappearing. Put simply, The Anchor and Hope produces some of the greatest food in London. But it also refuses to take reservations (I'm never quite sure why). So you, dear customer, must take a chance on whether you'll get to eat there. But if you do, you'll be amazed. This place understand pigeons and pork, charcuterie and cassoulet like no other. And they serve Bombadier. Enough said.

rdlx0IppRSM1TGSYgYgdLA.text: Anchor & Hope, I wanted to love you.  But sadly, my hopes were dashed.So this was what happened.  We fled the Old Vic after a particularly snooze-inducing The Tempest.  The night was getting cold and windy.  With high hopes, we rushed down the street to the buzzing warm embrace of Anchor & Hope.  The front room was already half empty, although still buzzing, when we walked in.  A waitress saw us and asked if we wanted a table.  She proceeded to grab a menu (a single sheet of printed paper), and motioned us to the nearby bar table.  She crossed out a few items on the Starters list.  "These are out."  She then crossed out the whole lower half section of the Mains.  Then she said, "These are all out.  Instead, we have..." and started writing on the blank space at the top of the sheet.  "Scottish Kippers, simply grilled, the only proper way to cook kippers, with a pat of butter on top."  "Braised duck leg with carrots and peas."  She looked up at us and said, "This is what we have.  Are you still interested?"Walking into the dining room, the crowd was loud, and we squeezed our way to a 2-top in the corner.  It was the only empty table in the room.  After we settled in, and decided on a Verdicchio from the Marche, we looked at the scratched-out and scribbled-in menu in front of us.  In the end, we got the following:  Hereford Beef Carpaccio, Octopus in Aioli, Grilled Kipper, and Braised Duck Leg.  The carpaccio arrived.  A plate of raw, red beef, topped with a mess of rocket.  The beef were about  1/2 inch thick slices, and not dressed at all.  The arugula were barely dressed with oil.  I suppose a carpaccio at an English gastropub is not the same as a carpaccio at Harry's Bar.  Not having embraced a Paleolithic diet now popular with a certain demographic, we took a few bites and were overjoyed that the octopus has arrived.  This dish had a lot of pungent garlic flavor in the aioli, but the octopus had the texture of canned cephalopod.  Trust me, i've had canned squid, i know.  We ended up using the sauce in the octopus to dress the beef.  Next came the kipper, with a wedge of lemon.  The fish was smoky and salty on the outside, but sweet and mild on the inside.  Needless to say, the fish was gone in a flash.  Lastly, the duck leg.  A perfect braise, if a tad on the salty side.  The carrot and peas only provided some mushy texture, as all I could taste was salt.Why 2 stars?  I suppose after what happened, do I need to explain further?  The story itself is certainly priceless.  Perhaps on another visit and under different circumstances, Anchor & Hope deserves another try.  But until then...

oSAsLzGYEsthIgs2ZiUSOw.text: I frequented the Anchor & Hope while living in Waterloo.  Always dependable for a delicious gastro-meal.  They always had a solid real ale on tap and amazing specials.  I found service very friendly and informative.  I always wanted to grab one of the specials for 4 or more, but I was never able.  Regardless every meal I had there was spectacular.

Ev5AYI7UM2KHElMbWRleWw.text: There are few destination Gastro pubs in Britain. Some of us are lucky enough to have some near our homes. Apart from The Eagle on Farringdon Road where on some days you can get a beautifully cooked Onglet with a red wine and shallott reduction , I would normally not cross town for a Gastro Pub meal. However I'm now finding I need a fix at least once a week. It's a place where you can enjoy world class bourgeois cooking like , Cassoulet , Ox Cheek stew with Dumplings , Slow cooked Tamworth ( along with Gloucsester Old Spot the only edible pork in Britain) with sauerkraut , Lanchashire Hot Pot , great soups and decent deserts. Go in a group and share some of the dishes for 4 or 3 that come in rustic looking pipping hot Le Creuset cookware ! The people who run the place have excellent backgrounds at The Eagle and the St John.

MfcfHwW487dQnrQIaNocvA.text: Good re-fueling point if you're site seeing around the South Bank. The food is good with a very large selection, however there are so many pubs like this in London that it doesn't seem to stand out as anything outstanding against the rest. They do have a very nice beer selection and huge outdoor seating area, if it's ever warm enough for that!

2MJLMLlV_nGSjTzw_8aOwQ.text: The staff clearly love what they do, and you can taste it. A relaxed place for food-lovers.

IcpYgEW2mAQ7UccUIVsNLA.text: Really amazing place!  Came in close to closing time, and the host/server took our order before we even sat, so that the kitchen wouldn't  close on us.  Recommended some amazing dishes, which we chose, and then came back to regretfully tell use that those dishes weren't available.  I eventually ordered a fish dish, which was incredible!  She and the kitchen folk still felt bad for us because  she knew I was jonesin' for meat, yet they were out of the two dishes I was keying in on.  So while we sat waiting on our stuff, she brought out some tasty prosciutto ham and pickles, and then two breaded rabbit legs--on the house!  It was amazing.  M'lady had this tasty vegetarian pot pie thing that was basically scalloped potatoes in a flaky crust.  Everything was great.  Other tables were working on these dishes that I guess you had to order an hour or so ahead, but they came in these big square/rectangular 3 inch deep pans, and they were filled with these brontesaurus sized pieces of meat and juices that the people at the table would cut and serve and share.  I wanted some of that.  Tanget.  Anyway, what we had was amazing.  Good atmosphere.  Kinda what i'd imagine that Spotted Pig was going after in NYC, only with better (read, slightly brighter) lighting.  If they had what I wanted initially, i'd have given them five stars, but major points for their reaching to make us happy. And in the end, we were.

XKh8cpb6_t4Rfm6NOkhihg.text: Lunched there three times and had dinner twice. Each time the menu was interesting and the food excellent. The wine was also very good, if not cheap. In fact, nothing was cheap, but it was good value.Service is pub like, but at the table. The food was expertly prepared and interesting--trying hard interesting but generally successful. I'll go back atain.

wPxlX121KiPi7DV-z-HNrA.text: Thank you, UK Yelpers! Our first night in London and we scored big with a night at The Anchor and Hope. The menu (which changes daily) seemed a bit intimidating at first...(ox heart, lamb's neck?) but once you commit, dive in and decide to be a tad adventurous The Anchor and Hope can set you on a course for food nirvana.The staff was friendly at the tiny gastropub. There was no clear indication of how things worked here. No hostess or anything. I eventually asked the bartender about getting a table inside the adjoining dinning room, which is divided from the bar area by a curtain and he pointed and said, "talk to David."After finding David we did have to wait awhile, but no complaints here as we enjoyed some beer and a yummy Dark and Stormy cocktail.When we got to our table we had already chosen our meals. I opted for a pork dish with apples and my husband settled on a leek and cheese dish. I have to say that my husband chose best. We are still talking about his snail salad. YUM!After dinner we met some lovely Brits who were actually surprised two American tourists had found this little gem."Yelp," I replied.

ruqh47btvZBW6LQMA11ddQ.text: love the variety on the menu; fit for gastropub foodies. they had an amazing rabbit special and a whole sea bass that wasn't overcooked or over-seasoned.extra points for the waitress pronouncing my friend's super long last name correctly

IhPyU04NRdceiaoFM_xefQ.text: Hands down, the best gastropub in London. Whenever I go to the Tate Modern, I go to the Anchor and Hope. And as I am an artist, that is a lot. I love the atmosphere, the vibe, and everything about this little gem.  I usually meet friends there and typically am the first to arrive. I grab a seat at the bar and order a carafe of wine. Another can't miss if you are a foodie like me

XqHVtFFGz4oT0wkFzoQ2UA.text: Went here based on some of the positive reviews while working in London (from DC originally).  Had to wait about 45 minutes on a Tuesday night which I though was odd, but turned out to be a good sign.  We had a few beers at the bar while we waited and were seated.  The seating is communal and 2 of us were at a 6 top with 2 groups of 2 people.  I didn't realize this was the scheme, but everything turned out fine.  Ordered the Rib for two with Bernaise and chips and it was flawless.  Huge portion, crispy chips and the Bernaise had a hint of something I don't normally associate with bernaise, but it was still good.  Topped the night off with some wine to wash down the steak and was on my way.  Would recommend to anyone looking for a good meal and some well poured beers.

2JjBnhMNh2h2RVdD3mnmqA.text: I was very excited about my visit to The Anchor and Hope as it came very recommended. So what better than a romantic meal out with the other half on Friday night. Good food and amazing company surely can't fail to satisfy?I had been warned that they didn't take reservations, and as I peered into the overflowing bar my fingers were tightly crossed for a table. And as luck would have it two seats were available immediately on a table of six with two other couples. So much for the romantic meal.The tightly packed dining room is gastropub classic with wooden tables and odd chairs and wine served in goblets (unless you buy the expensive stuff). For such a small dining area there were a lot of staff dashing around in what I'm hoping was organised chaos - although despite the numbers it was hard at times to grab someones attention.As per usual I was taking sneaky peeks at other people's tables and food probably very rude, but who cares. The menu isn't hugely varied, lots of meat and fish, but all the portions looked very healthy indeed.So to the food.Starters were a Radicchio and Saffron Risotto and Pigs Head Vinaigrette. Pigs head I hear you cry. Well not a whole one. It was really just brawn. Served at room temperature the fat was tepid and unappetising. The risotto was more of an oily rice, not the creamy indulgence I was expecting. It was certainly stuffed with saffron though.Mains were several notches up. Both the Half Lobster and Corn on the Cob and the Baked Wild Sea Trout with Beetroot and Samphire were glittering combinations of taste and colour. The sweet succulent lobster meat performing a little tango with the most amazing corn I've had for a long time - crunchy and sweet - all moulded together with melted butter. The cold sea trout dish produced a perfectly cooked fish with the tingling surprise of pickled cucumber and sweet beetroot.But the hit of the evening had to be the dessert. Strawberry Tart. But not just any strawberry tart. The Strawberry Tart. Buttery melt in your mouth pastry encasing a moist hazelnut filling topped with juicy strawberries. You'll be pleased to know that I did share with my other half, but only a couple of fork-fulls and only because his cheese platter really wasn't up to much.At £85 for two including a bottle of wine I found it a bit steep. This is certainly a restaurant to come as a group with excellent deals like a whole roast seabass or rib of beef for two or a seven hour lamb shoulder to share with 4 of your closest friends. Food 3.5/5 - The Strawberry Tart gave the edgeService 3/5 - A bit slow but very cheeryEnvironment 3/5 - Typical gastropub just small and tight.

KbU7wWfCM1YlTMETyCwR-Q.text: I came here on a very cloudy afternoon for lunch with my boyfriend after a morning spent wandering around London. I really loved the decor. The restaurant felt so warm despite the damp chilly weather. I ordered the Confit Duck with lentils after asking our waiter for a recommendation since I was debating between a couple of dishes. I would love to come back to The Anchor & Hope when I am in London again.

J-7XDQHODzioCT58TmBBDw.text: This is a surprisingly popular gastro pub. I would say that it is boisterous, boozy and chaotic -- all in positive ways. The dining room is brilliant, food is without pretnceless and the service is laid back. It is the perfect place to relax an afternoon away.

u_uDwkdRgARaYOaeYQr1Fg.text: I always find myself wanting to rate with a half star and this is another time.  I think The Anchor and Hope is a solid 4.5.  Last Friday, after a gruelling workout, six people from the gym went out  to launch a birthday celebration.  After two hours of real ale, we all realized that if we didn't get some food immediately there would be serious problems.   Someone in the group suggested The Anchor and Hope so we walked there with purpose.  We saw a line of people waiting for tables when we entered at 10:25 and found out the kitchen closes at 10:30 so we figured it was a lost cause.  I asked one of the waiters if there was any chance of a table and he told me he would check and see.  I didn't see his face for five minutes and we were afraid the answer would be "no," so we left to find nourishment.  After going about half a block, we heard the man from The Anchor and Hope calling us back into the restaurant.  It was unexpected and extremely appreciated.  The man took our orders before we were seated so he could get them into the kitchen as soon as possible.  I looked at the chalk board menu (most things were crossed off because they cook fresh daily) and nothing really caught my eye, but I was told one of the replacement dishes was lasagne for two and my husband and I ordered it immediately.  The starters came out shortly after we were seated.  I shared a snail and bacon salad.  There were large portions of each on a bed of warm  lettuce.  Someone ordered the soup and managed to say the broth tasted homemade in between rapid slurps.   Oak smoked salmon was also ordered and devoured quickly.  The lasagne was served in a large oval  cast iron dish and we found it to be a delicious cheesy, meaty mess.  It filled my husband and I completely and there was still enough to give a scoop or two to others at the table.  The noodles were outnumbered by the cheese and beef and if it was served with tortilla chips it would have made a nice dip.  Pure decadence.  Dishes like this are why I go to the gym.  Three people ordered the rabbit.  Its portion size was also big and we saw a few people in the restaurant with little tinfoil purses taking food home so that seemed to be par for the course.  I found the meat a little dry and salty, but my friends finished their meals.  Another person ordered the duck and said it was the best she had ever had.  It was falling off the bone moist without the fattiness you sometimes experience with duck.  We each ordered dessert and those dishes were also licked clean.  I enjoyed a little chocolate pot with cream on top.  The liquid topping, hard outer shell and moist dark chocolate inside provided three nice textures.  The buttermilk pudding with rhubarb and spiced oranges was just okay.  It was akin to a bland flan and could have used more rhubarb.  The person next to me made quick work of the little lemon pot.  It was a great meal with fantastic service.  I definitely recommend The Anchor and Hope.

gDLBM1NpqKQdT1DwmYy3Fw.text: So, faced with an evening doing my tax return, I decided the best way to warm up was to sit in a pub with a cocktail and my book for an hour before wheeling home to grapple with a bag of receipts and several utterly incomprehensible access codes. The Anchor and Hope has fantastic cocktails. On the rare occasions I've managed to squeeze in before, a friend and I have hunkered at the bar and got stuck into the cheap, small measures. They do Sidecars, which is fantastic. In fact, the whole menu is pleasantly old school  Americans, Negronis, Dark and Stormys, and so on. The major problem with the A&H is, ironically, how good it is. I've wanted to eat at The Anchor and Hope for ages. Seeing as I live a tramp's stumble from its front door, this shouldn't have been hard, but every time I've passed it it's been rammed. You have to mentally prepare yourself to go there as it's rarely filled at anything less than scrum capcity. There are a couple of tables where you can hide away from other people's elbows, bags and knees, but it's not a tremendously great place to unwind. I decided the tax return needed to be put off for at least another cocktail's worth, so called up the boyfriend and asked if he'd like a break from crap weather and work and to come to dinner. After waiting an hour or so for a table, we were slotted on to the end of another table which was a bit of a surprise. Some people like this, I really don't unless you're at Wagamamas. But hey-ho. A waitress immediately got us some bread (two slices, delicious. I accidentally ate most of it much to the amused disapproval of my boyfriend). I had the starter of duck's heart and radicchio risotto as my main course, boyfriend had the hare. I've never had hare before and am kicking myself: unctuous, impossibly dark meat that melted in the mouth with a wistful Animals of Farthing Wood aftertaste. The risotto was a good risotto, the duck's heart could have been a mushroom. Not much more to say about that really. Boyfriend had pecan pie and ice cream (I wrestled a pecan from it, pretty good) and I had a scoop of salted chocolate ice cream. Ordinarily I'm not keen on chocolate ice cream but love the sweet/salt mix. This could have done with a smidgeon more salt to make it proper orgasm on a plate, but was still nice enough. The staff are impeccable. They must have some secret genome that lends them good looks, saint-like patience, manners and good waiting ability despite working in the SE1 equivalent of London Zoo. I was utterly mortified last night to pay the bill by card, ignoring the service charge as always, and then reaching into my purse to find out I didn't have any change. Next time I pass, I'll throw in some pound coins and hope they hit their mark, because as decent as the food and drink is, the Anchor and Hope is too stressful to bother with again. As it is, it really doesn't need another fan, it's already well over capacity.

zJDn5lSvWsF07XUa4HL87g.text: Had been looking forward to going to The Anchor & Hope for a while. Went for a late lunch in the hope that we would be able to get a table reasonably quickly. We got a table immediately. Service began well and then deteriorated but I think that was because the service was coming to an end. Really liked the menu overall, although the special of steak pie didn't sound that special to me. They close the kitchen at 2.30PM and we were lucky enough to get our order in at about 2.25pm. The meals came quickly and were delicious. I opted for the potato and gubbeen pie which was hearty and delicious. Serving sizes are huge here which is something I appreciate because it means I can fit dessert. Once we got our mains the service was really patchy. We had to remind the waitress about our drink orders as well as reminding her that we would like to have dessert. The desserts were delicious, I had the trifle. Not impressed that they don't do decaf coffee as one of our party cannot drink caf coffee. Overall, will definitely go back as the food was extremely well prepared and delicious, but I agree with other comments that they need to work on their service.

HFkAhPsi6_cFIQtjbhgJaQ.text: So I said I always wanted to come back here and try the food and as good as my word I did.  As stated in my previous review, be aware that they don't take bookings and are very popular, so get here early or be prepared to chill out in the bar and wait.  We turned up about 6 and got a table at their first serving which I think was about 6.30.We had Cured Sea Trout (they had cured the trout themselves) and Roast Rib of Beef with Bernaise sauce and Steak Fries (cooked to order - 40mins) which was just amazing.  So much rare, succulent beef with the most amazingly crispy/fluffy fries washed down with a bottle of chilled Beaujolais.  Fantastic.Although getting a table can be a trauma, once you're seated, things couldn't be more relaxed.  There is no sense of having to get done so others can take your table at all, you're there till your done and not before.This place is a foodies delight.  If you're serious about food; come and eat here - it's fantastic.

oefVfG2MjWhUFsn0jXdJ7Q.text: Enjoyed dinner here with colleagues from work on a Friday night. The beer selection was not spectacular so just chose a draft on cask. The food was definitely homemade and very good.

Rg6ENsThGjvCC-l8SWHm9w.text: Beware, for this is not a typical gastro-pub. This is certainly not a quick eat-and-go place. Anchor & Hope is strictly for those who treasure a good gastronomic experience and are willing to slug it out for one. Although, it would be unfair to say that the possibly long wait for a table in this wee pub is equivalent of slugging it out. They have no cider on tap, but they had bottles of fine Devon cider to keep me suitably occupied. The bar area, on a Tuesday night, was choc-a-bloc with wooden stools, round tables and a whole lot of people - some might consider this annoying and noisy but I found it a fabulous exercise in people watching while catching up with a fellow foodie friend. We were eventually seated on a 6-seater with two of us on one end and a couple on the far end of the same table - we weren't terribly fussed, really. A few minutes later, after we had placed an order for the house wine and starters, the waitress came bustling towards us and apologised while asking us if we would mind moving to a 2-seater table next to us because they needed the table for a big group. We didn't mind it at all, but they said the wine would be on the house for the inconvenience - so big props on the service :)The house red was nice and so was the starter (I'm struggling to remember what this was, it was over a year ago, but I remember being well pleased with it) but what really clinched it for me would be the tenderly cooked duck in a sweet date sauce - indeed, a well made meal can be a joyful memory for a long time to come! My friend ordered a chicken which she found very delightful too. This was followed up with some brilliant chocolate mousse and at no point did we feel like we were being rushed through our email, despite the inevitable flurry of service staff dashing between tables.While not cheap, it is fairly inexpensive for a place that ranks consistently highly in gastro-pub ratings.I wonder why I haven't been to A&H since that wonderful meal, this review reminds me that I need to make a trek to the Cut soon!

zQC_Yl9cLOSFTyzzNW4FSg.text: This A&H attracts the young-ish working crowd, by my estimation from late 20's to mid 30's.  One can retreat to the modest outdoor seating area if it becomes too crowded inside, especially on Thursday and Fridays.  Ciggie run is a breeze with a Costcutter just across The Cut.

2a7OFZ8OF1WSaPTor73nGw.text: I definitely like the whole gastropub angle, but not so much the waiting an hour for a table angle. Sometimes you get in, sometimes you don't, that's just how life is, I guess. But enough of my homespun wisdom, let's just stick to the Anchor and Hope.I like the dim lighting, makes everyone look more attractive. And the drink selection is great. The food was really yummy but not as amazing as I had hoped. I think this is because I went really late and had the one main that was still available. So there's your lesson. Go late and you have a better chance of getting in without a wait, but go early and you get a better dinner. Go forth and get gastroed out of it.

iAuNWTe5QrLQYIh1Xehx4Q.text: A simply fabulous dinner. A great cassoulet and a lovely berry-like Spanish red. Would come back in a NY minute

Vjq7pOVGqoyBb8W8p43w-w.text: I never expect these types of places to live up to their reputations but this one did--and then some--all thanks to a little bunny!  First of all, while I hear this place is impossible to get into at dinner and late into the night, it was relatively easy to snag a table for 2 at lunch.  I started with a serviceable beetroot salad...the beets were extremely sweet and fresh...but nothing spectacular here.  Then came the wild rabbit.  It was rich and gamy perfectly complimented by a moderately garlicky sauce and large beans.  A cool pint of ale was a perfect accompaniment.  When the waiter asked if I wanted dessert, I thought for a moment and decided the taste in my mouth was so good, I didn't want to change it.  That's saying a lot.Maybe next time...

YD76gZPIvGKnShl6GKqaoA.text: We had a great meal at the Anchor & Hope.  What a nice find in the South Bank area.  Five of us shared two "family style" meals for 3 people.  We had the pot roasted duck and a roast lamb shoulder.  Both were fantastic.  The breads were nice, service first rate.  Atmosphere was very casual.  Well worth a visit.

jX7Z5j0YiBJuP5E1bUe9Ww.text: Hmmmm( in a contemplative way rather than satisfied way), the drink was so so, they didn't bring one of our side dishes and the fish was far from special. In truth you get better value for money, food and service  at Canteen on the SouthBank. My Plaice was not worth £16. I am not a food snob but I think I may head towards the Thames next time.The ambiance was very nice it is a shame the food and drink didn't match.

OT9sMvCdelyKDasoz-mhTQ.text: What  a lovely little gastropub. We went out for lunch undecided about where we were going to eat. Some of my lunch companions mentioned this place, but in the same breath also said, "Oh, we're probably not going to get in, it's always rammed."  But we decided to take a chance and in we walked to a table for five. From the off, it's worth saying that the menu is not your traditional gastropub menu. It apparently changes on a weekly basis and when we went, the menu was full of offal and game - think pig's head and duck hearts.  I'm not really one for these more hard-core cuts of meat, so I opted for the semolina gnocchi with chicory leaves and St. Teo goat's cheese. I know now that I don't like chicory, but the gnocchi and goat's cheese were just sublime. This wasn't traditional gnocchi though. It came in two very flat rectangles with quite a lot of St. Teo's on top. Really delicious and well balanced. What a great place. I can imagine a lot of boozy lunches here in the future.

MH91cOvsVSYamjLHHrc3Rg.text: One of my favorite places in London. Best for bringing visitors to show them what relaxed and seasonal British food is all about.  The wait can be long, but there is a good buzz around the bar area and I always manage to find a nice spot to wait before the table is ready.

k8gKm1XJcTzmT5DlO2qR1g.text: Yummy, yummy, yummy. Simple gastro pub food accompanied by gorgeous wine in a very relaxed atmosphere.  Will be desperately trying to recreate the slow cooked lamb dish at home very soon.It's busy though so if you want to eat you need to get there early as they don't take bookings.

6wskb-DxhZaaQ_Z35bNCLg.text: Are you a restaurant masochist who loves to be treated badly?  Do you like to go to a restaurant and wait for several hours because they don't take reservations?  Do you want to be harried and crowded in and smile and tip 15% when you get bad service? Do you want to be so hungry when you get the food that flavour is irrelevant and it is just time to feed the pit?If so, the Anchor and Hope is for you.  And I had to force myself, deny myself, restrain myself from giving the place 5* because I love it even if it doesn't deserve my love.

3sCLlCxl8NXnGHoM8yeEig.text: The Anchor has ruined me with it's fish and chips. Try as I might, I have never found tastiness to that degree in the States. You go up the stairs (not in the regular dining area) and get your choice of fish with chips and mushy peas. Then you take your box of goodness straightaway to the covered area outside, which, when drizzly is lovely. It's right next to the river as well, so it's a pretty place for lunch. My frend and I miss the crispy deliciousness, but I will be back before I die.

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor and Hope - London, United Kingdom

f5dIjdVLxqa0-MF0CUsIzw.text: Everytime I am in London, I want to eat here.  Last time I decided I would try their sister gastropub, Great Queen Street, which was nice but nowhere near as delicious and wonderful as The Anchor and Hope.Run, don't walk.  Especially if you (wrongly) think that all British food is tasteless, overboiled and fried.A particular favourite of mine is Sunday lunch.  There really is no competition anywhere for the spread.  It is also the only meal for which you can reserve a table.  And I seriously suggest you do.

0ceQPd3u1EcsNzLthPVxIg.text: Better than fabulous, I simply love the A&H. I've been fortunate to be eating here pretty much since it opened and I have never had a bad meal. Staff are always friendly and helpful despite being run off their feet at every service. I have occasionally waited for a table but then it's not as if the no reservations policy is a secret. Why do people whinge about it when the upside is that whatever day you want to go and eat there you can simply roll up, ask for a table, have a drink at the bar and then eat an extraordinarily good meal.

NxIHn7l7pv_bqg0tmFfQUA.text: Terrible service. Waiter told us he'd be right back with menus.. twenty minutes later we gave up waiting and left.

UiGTfO36UIQcEyH3szbWMg.text: I haven't been in months and I still remember with fondness how blown away I was by their rhubarb ice cream.They didn't get five stars because you have to wait forever to be seated, and that whole process seems pretty sporadic...

wyCvqNuvKlyTaCBwWC4stw.text: I've been wanting to eat here for a while. A previous attempt with some friends from out of town was abandoned since we weren't  patient enough to stand  with a bunch other people pushed into the corner of the pub on the off chance we might actually secure a table. They don't take bookings.This time we had an excuse to go early before the theatre so checked in at 5:30 and got on the list for a 6pm table which is when the evening session starts. At 6pm, the lucky groups, including us, filtered into the dining area which is separated off from the pub area.The dining interior is fairly cramped with wooden tables and chairs, similar to the pub area.Menu looked good. British classics with one or two continental offerings thrown in (andouillette sausage for example). Sustaining meat and fish dishes and hearty puddings. I like this simple kind of no frills food.I had the potato soup with crisp bacon as a starter. Food came quite quickly as the kitchen swung into full steam ahead and suitably rustic bread was brought along with water (no attempt to upcharge for bottled which is good). The soup was OK but reminded me of thinned down mashed potato and the bacon wasn't crisp but more like slightly dried out ham. I know it's a simple dish but I have had potato soup that has been quite memorable. I do like the idea of very simple dishes that can be made special.For mains I had the middle white pork with prunes and mashed potato. The dish was perfectly acceptable and well executed but nothing special to note. My dining companions had the lemon sole which was reported to also be quite good but not too exciting.Some decent and reasonably priced wine selections, with wine served in a tumbler, utilitarian style to match the rest of the concept.Since the portion sizes weren't huge despite the heavy sounding descriptions, we had room for desert so opted for a date or fig (can't remember exactly) pudding with whiskey sauce and clotted cream. I was expecting a warm, melt in the mouth steamed pudding. What came was a wodge of slightly heavy and slightly dry  loaf cake served cold, slightly dry with some dcent whiskey flavoured sauce and dollop of clotted cream. Again, OK but not as good as I was anticipating. Should have had the Queen of Puddings instead perhaps.Service was efficient  and prompt.Overall A-OK sums it up well for me taking into account the food and value for money. With the price tag approaching £40 a head I have eaten better at other gastro pub or restaurants serving similar themed British food. Good enough but wouldn't rush back. It's puzzling since the place has such a reputation as one of the best gastro pubs. Maybe a victim of it's own success since there is a queue out of the door or maybe other places have just got much better or perhaps just wasn't the best night here since others rate it more highly.

p0G00GS9oCFExnXrb6uyqg.text: Ridiculously tasty and affordable! I got the wood pigeon and mash and I almost licked the plate at the end! Apparently the menu changes often but everything on there looked great, the hardest thing was to pick one. I went on a Friday and wet got seated straight away at a sharing table but the restaurant filed up pretty quick after that.

KUPfyj-qEiNKSwUOYCm64w.text: We stopped in here on a recent trip as it seemed highly recommended on various online forums. We got there at 6 and it was packed, which was a good sign. But it was pretty chaotic and no clear way to get a name down for a table or any such thing. We squeezed our way to the bar and got drinks and inquired about getting a table. The bartender sort of blew it off, telling us to find a "slender red-haired girl" to ask. Okay. I thought I spotted the person he may have been referring to, so I headed over her way, and as I rounded a corner, I became a momentary road block for a server coming through and he was not at all pleased. He asked if I needed a table and I said yes, to which he said to wait around the corner and he'd send the hostess over to us. Okay, that sounded good, despite the fact that he seemed clearly agitated with my mere presence in the building. Skeptical, I watched him closely and it became clear after 5 minutes or so that he had no intention of alerting any hostess. We gave it one last try, flagging down the possible red-headed hostess and were successful on our third try! We actually got a table pretty soon after that, after hanging in the bar area for 10-15 minutes. Long enough to see a couple people get served a delicious looking slice of porchetta that made me drool. By the time we sat, I knew I needed it. My husband ordered a couple appetizers for his meal - bacon-wrapped snails and pig's head. He liked everything very much. My porchetta, however, looked completely different from the slices even one table over from ours. Where the plates I saw earlier were pale, juicy looking, and about an inch thick, mine was pink and jagged - thick on one side and thin on the other. It wouldn't have mattered if it tasted good, but it didn't. It was pretty much inedible. I didn't bother trying to do anything about it given my already less than welcomed feeling. Oh well.. my sense was that it's overhyped. But the crowds definitely implied otherwise. Wish we had a better experience.

2Q2zIkv0BmFUUms6jPThzA.text: I loved this place, the vibe, the atmosphere, the 'mission', so to speak, and the food.  The idea of the Gastropub is starting to appear in NYC too, and it's exciting.I was amazed at just how many people there were inside, and dismayed for the long wait for a table and by the incredibly loud noise of said people chatting in the bar area.  (It was better later after we sat down, but not much...)The menu was creative and interesting (rabbit, or venison, anyone?) and everything I tried - I was with 2 mates - was very tasty and not overwhelmingly large or heavy.  That includes the venison I tried, which can be an exceedingly heavy, gamey dish.  I had a sort of gratin with cauliflower, and a deliciously simple tomato soup to start.  Good bread was included, and at the end we split some desserts, including a fabulous banana split and flourless chocolate cake.  Yummmmm!  I would love to go back on my next trip to London.  Perhaps a less-busy time of night would be ideal to be there.

opiMuNXulNmMAUOjTk8Tng.text: Believe the hype. This is a great pub. Great food. Lovely service. Reasonably priced. Everything works

photos.caption: Photo of The Anchor and Hope - London, United Kingdom. Good times at The Anchor and Hope

tJjD3Jf2PBdMYW3HCchpcw.text: Our first visit to this venue was one of the highlights of my summer so far - so it had a lot to live up to!On our second visit we arrived to find a queue of people waiting to book a table. With no bookings taken over the phone/a first come first serve system, there's always the worry that someone will need to get there quickly from work to secure a table before 9pm. The staff are efficient, fair and friendly though which means it's a less stressful experience to get on that all important list than it might be with the wrong person managing the bookings.The bar was pleasantly busy, with a good rotation of space, as the lucky people (there before you) are called to their table in the main restaurant.The barmen were pretty busy which is why it meant all the more that the gentleman looking after me (I wish I'd got his name) really took some time to help me navigate the wine list. Faced with a selection of grapes that I wasn't familiar with, he allowed me to try one or two wines before settling on a delicious bottle Chianti which stayed delicious through out the next 2 bottles with dinner!We didn't have to wait too long to be seated - about 40mins and we had had some bread and butter to keep us going. The gentleman serving us was the same as before, a lovely fellow with a distinctive moustache and friendly yet professional manner. Generally this is a meat heavy meal. I'm sure they provide well for vegetarians but I have to say I didn't check, as once you start on the menu your mouth starts watering with their descriptions of choices such as Goat, mounds of beef, Steak, Leg of Lamb, chicken etc. One potential downside is that they only plan for a certain amount of dishes each night so when it's gone it's gone. On our second visit we were caught out by this and had to forfeit the lamb (which had been the best dish on our previous visit).For starters the squid was delicious and not too chewy like it can so often be. I enjoyed the lobster soup, although my partner thought is was a bit too this (you cant please everyone!)The best idea for main courses is to team up, as the portions are usually for 2 or more...you don't need to pick your battle buddy carefully though, as you certainly wont leave hungry.For mains, the Steak/Beef was amazing. Wedges of beef that were both tasty and easy to chew. Honestly, it takes a lot for me to enjoy beef or steak, as I usually find it really chewy, even when others say it's not - I have some theory about evolution here but I'll leave that for another time!The goat was delicious - a meat that a lot of people wouldn't necessarily order but they have no idea what they're missing out on and this was perfectly cooked.My chicken was a little too fruity for me but a sneaky call for some Aioli made all the difference. By the way, The Anchor and Hope don't do sauces - I'm not sure if I agree with that or not...The aioli was definitely a winner though.To full for dessert - do they get that a lot? I'm guessing so.It's not cheap but worth the splurge occasionally with a group of friends who enjoy meat and wine!All round this is a lovely experience, as long as you can get there in good time to book a table before all the best food run out.

I_rb4Y9AV_2WBv1OXCg0KQ.text: Been in a couple of times. Can be nice, can be terrible. Food pops up and down, depending on if the experiment worked that day or not (folk: You're no Heston. Pick one: flavour or looks)Staff can be helpful or downright rude. You can't really tell. I'll be back. I sort of want to give it 4 and 2 stars, from my 2 visits... maybe the next one will settle it, but for now, I'll go with mean.

fF4jM_Cif-WkaIHBjjP_GA.text: Great atmosphere. Sophisticated food. Reasonable prices and good drinks. Really enjoyed the evening out. Recommend it for a lax night out with the lads.

AvnGxiqjNisP1jhsvi0GXA.text: Really tasty well cooked food in an unpretentious setting and at a good price.  The no reservations policy isn't a problem if you get there around 5:30.  The wait staff are polite - even letting a non eating member of our party  stay while we ate our starters.SO what you get is great British fare, deliciously simple.  I've had a lush neck of venison with a group of 5, flank steak for 2, the best damn rice pudding I've ever tasted, a succulent Dover sole, and always the snail and bacon salad when it's in season.Edit (Definitely 5 stars!)

c3fnqOTVEKu2Enne7XxiPw.text: Along with the Scarsdale Tavern, this is one of my top 3 London dining experiences. Just go and enjoy. Thank me later. Since they do not take reservations, be sure to check their website for tips on getting a table.  PS The braised meats are f-ing fantastic.

BcVo4taxuVp_RAtOxMomKA.text: Great pub with excellent atmosphere! I've been here a number of times for a drink and now have finally sampled the AMAZING food!You can't book here and it is usually very busy which does mean the service is a little erratic. But the food more than makes up for it. The menu has a good selection of dishes and many of them are "sharers". We had the lamb for 3 with potato dauphonise. The lamb melted in the mouth!For desert I had the poppy seed cheesecake which was the best cheesecake I've ever had... Considering deserts are usually a bit of a disappointment I was very impressed!Definitely worth queuing for!

GWguyRdgIHe_14qQ-B3vFg.text: I was informed (mostly from the reviews on this page) that the staff were rude but the beer was worth coming for. On the contrary the staff were very friendly and efficient but the beer salection was poor. Had a decent pint of Youngs but hardly worth making the trip for and the selection was pretty bog standard - Kirin, Guinness, Amstel. Plus marks for the no-frills cocktail list -  negroni, americano, mahattan, bloody mary etc. No fannying about with olde englishe recipes or overly elaborate modern interpretations.Black marks for the lack of imagination on tap and the ridiculous amount of tables stuffed into quite a poky space.

aAIBP7HRUvenBHrP6QdiJA.text: One of my favourites. Very convenient location and good place to meet when you have friends from different areas of London.As with the Eagle and 32 Great Queen Street, the food is robust, rustic, simple and delcious. Good value and the wines are fantastic.Reservations are not possible except for Sundays where they have a set menu that starts at 2pm.

m7F-NaoMB4Ahj4cuXKgEnw.text: Having lived in Waterloo for a year and spent much of my time in the area, invariably I had Anchor and Hope recommended to me, both by word of mouth and seeing it vaunted in Time Out et al as being a must-visit gem.Laziness and lack of persistence, alas, when taken in concert with it being borderline impossible to get a table without an hour+ wait (and they don't take reservations), meant that I never got to try it.Thankfully, having started working around the corner, I'd made this place number one priority on my list. A smarter man would have angled for lunch, but I was determined to get in there with some of my more foodie friends in the evening. Fate, it seems, was smiling on me on my second attempt - miraculously there was a table the exact size I needed, which was the only one available. So it was, after such torturous travails, FINALLY we were there, seated, and soon to be wowed.Firstly - I've heard various complaints about gruff service. As per usual, it's probably completely overstated, or they had one troublesome server who's since been booted. I figure that you get out what you put in - treat staff politely and cheerfully and they'll reciprocate. Act like a prize a***-hole and don't expect high levels of service. My experience was fine - sufficiently attentive, polite and helpful, I couldn't really ask for much more given the type of establishment.The food sounded absolutely sublime, so much so that we were struggling what to choose. We had settled on sharing asparagus, scallops and "duck ham" followed by a mixture of Middle White pork and breast of lamb (wonderful to see this cut starting to make its way on to menus), until eyes lit up when daily specials were read out - not only was there rabbit offal (liver, kidney and lungs) to tempt us away, but a monstrous 4-5 person shoulder of veal. Needless to say, this overtook everything else and we settled on scrapping starters and diving straight in to a whole joint of baby cow. On the veal issue - given its hue after being cooked, I presumed this was rose veal. If so, a commendable sourcing decision.It came in a huge casserole dish with root vegetables and a wonderful accompanying stock. Meat was so perfectly done it simply fell off the bone (though being furnished with tongs, sharp knife, carving fork and a large spoon meant there was the opportunity for plenty of ceremony too!) and was still a delightful soft pink on the inside. Superb quality meat, expertly executed in a very simple manner - what more could you ask for.We washed all of this down with a delightful (and fairly priced) Corbieres, though the rest of the wine list looked reasonable too.In truth, it is early days to be able to judge the Anchor & Hope after only one visit. Or at least that's what I keep telling myself. Clearly, for the sake of taking one for the Yelp team and providing only the most well-informed reviews, I will have to endure this experience again. Woe is me.

RM8TgPUoKfcjxvORJnwDXw.text: Look, I love food, but I hate rude people and uppity hipsters.  So there are things that I will put up with to get a really superb meal, but I didn't think we would get it here, and I wasn't willing to put up with the rudeness of the staff or some of the other patrons, so we didn't actually eat here.  Super crowded on a Friday night.  We came in at 8pm to find that most of what we wanted to eat had been sold out -- the only things left that looked good were the squab and halibut (or was it some other big white-fleshed ocean-going fish?) for 2.  Some of the remaining dishes just didn't sound appealing (confit duck leg with bacon and mint = fat, fat, and mint) -- which is likely the reason why they were still available.  After waiting 40 minutes for a table (and watching some of our fellow patrons try to jump the table queue -- they were English too!) and getting bitched out when trying to get a table in the bar (by the same people trying to jump the table queue), we left.  A Burberry trench and Bottega Venta bag do not equate to special treatment.  (Btw, my BF had just proposed that evening, so I was super bummed to be treated like dirt...)Several tables had been sitting empty for a while in the dining area, so it wasn't clear why we were waiting.  I think most of the problem is that they're getting popular (perhaps due to yelp?) and really need some technology to keep track of patrons -- something more than harried, rude guy with a clipboard.  Buzzers, anyone?  Also, the homeless guy who cursed us out when we left was just the icing on the cake.  I wouldn't go back even if the chef got a michelin star.

ALvydBSV2pg9s9xLZYMXSw.text: Small and intimate, this gastropub serves some of the most outlandish and eccentric English cuisine I've ever seen. Just brilliant.The pub is on The Cut within spitting distance of Waterloo Station and is separated into two distinct halves - one restaurant, one bar. That said, you can eat in the bar too. The kitchen is totally open, giving a great atmosphere and a host of smells.They don't take reservations, so it's a case of turn up and get a drink while a table becomes available. They'll put your name down for a table in the restaurant if you want, but we managed to poach a big table in the bar early on. The furniture is old and mismatched. While this might be trendy and stylish, the choice of chairs we had was verging on treacherous as we wobbled and balanced our way through our meal.The menu seems to change on a daily basis (given by the date at the top of the A4 inkjet printed menu). We plumped for the seven hour roasted shoulder of lamb, shared between three. Furnished with a huge carving knife and plates, we quickly munched through what seemed to be half a sheep. It was tender and delicious. It was £47 for three people, including a generous helping of potatoes dauphinoise.Drinks were very reasonable, with a decent selection of beers and cocktails. Try the Espresso Martini (£5).

XOWntgwBIh83zVqcGj0YQQ.text: Love this gastropub. Food has always been good and menu changes frequently. Wine list is great too.

4LVEqrD-sA6SWJPfHYSRFA.text: The Anchor & Hope recently underwent major refurbishment. Well, the refurbishment took ages, but to me it looks exactly the same now than it did then.Love the deep red walls and thrown together pine furniture.I went for lunch and had a really pleasant experience. The staff were extremely friendly and helpful. I didn't have to wait long for a table (shared) and the food was excellent.Many of the items on the menu are rather off-putting for non-carnivores (snails, fois gras, blood cake), but there are plently of fish dishes, as well as at least one veggie option for starters and mains.The hype seems to have died down a bit now; I'll definitely come back. With a bit of luck it will also be possible to have a meal in the evening :-)

AWHHYnTuqmUcokqFuMN3jw.text: Okay so after drooling over the food here when I went for a drink I managed to organise a lunch here just so I could sample the delights. I have to say, if you're vegetarian avoid eating here, your choice is limited and the daily changing menu will just make you frustrated.So I had the weirdest Gnocchi ever. It came as a slab with a dollop of goats cheese curd on top and some log bitter stringy greens that were actually slightly red. I'm not selling it am I? Well it was fabulous. Really beautiful food, perfectly cooked and served by suitably attractive and surly men. I'm not going to 5 star this place, sorry. It's fab but did wasn't knocked off my chair by it.

u5LHuS14RXLkIF7o-HgzQg.text: Stopped by for a bite of food and a pint with a friend after visiting the Tate Modern. We were lucky to score a spot at a counter as the place was bustling and vibrant at 9ish on a Saturday night. The menu changes daily or you might even say hourly as specials disappear as the night goes on. Fortunately everything was delicious and our slightly limited options didn't mean we didn't end up with amazing food. My dish of roasted pumpkin over soft polenta was prepared perfectly and matched wonderfully by the cheese, chestnuts, and kale on the dish.

UpXA3qjrhUgYmQW5-I8WrQ.text: Just had a delightful meal!  I travel for work, so I have to eat meals alone frequently - this place was great.  Be warned - there is the bar area, which you see when you enter, and then the main dining area, which is a bit hidden.  I found a server and asked him where to sit - he placed at a 6-top where there were two separate pairs eating, so be prepared for communal dining if that's where you fit.  Had a very delicious potato, chestnut and Adrahan (cheese) pie.  Was a stromboli-type pie - great flaky crust rolled around paper thin potato slices, lots of cheese.  Came with a nice watercress/radicchio salad and two pickled walnuts which were a VERY nice little treat.   For dessert: Buttermilk pudding, stewed Bramleys and salted caramel sauce.  YUMMMMMM.  The pudding was REALLY nice, light, vanilla bean dotted.  Delicious.Have added this to my "return to the next time I am here" list.

mn-n1WsTe3_ThAP4X5CcWA.text: Great food! It is a little cramped inside but it's totally worth because the food is AMAZING. It's gluten free friendly but if you're not celiac and want to have a good cheat the bread they serve you is wicked good.

-8iFtuD3JHuYkcI4k7l-9w.text: In the short span of time that we were in London, my fellow foodie friend and I ate here twice.  Neither time were we disappointed.  I had a soufflé the first time and a pumpkin and parmesan tart the second.  Finished by a peach tart the first time and a buttermilk pudding the second.  Both times I had a chicken based soup and they served bread to start.  The portions are perfect, leaving you enough room to enjoy a nibble of bread with it or not if you choose.  The ingredients are fresh, so fresh in fact they change their menu daily to accommodate seasonal ingredients and tastes.  The only complaint I have is that we had to wait in a completely packed bar for nearly an hour to get a table.  But my spin on eating out is never to eat at a place that is not busy at a meal time or that the locals will not go to.  This place is neither.  We enjoyed it immensely.  I will return on future trips to London, cheers!

Pfw8wIrCVxyrC2K0HwtBSg.text: I really enjoy this pub, especially the outdoor seating!  I love sitting by the Thames with a glass of wine and I try to come here as much as I can, but unfortunately a lot of people have the same idea, so it's tough to get a spot sometimes.  The service is quick and friendly and the prices are great.  I'm looking forward to many more visits here in the new year!!

eV0BKErZtI9h5Jka_U7CDw.text: Great food here as usual. No point in recommending any dish though as the menu is so changeable.The one thing that did annoy me is the minuscule glasses. Fine for water, but a bit silly if you order a cocktail. It's all a bit cramped. It's also a little expensive for what you get, but enjoyable and a nice place to stop before the theatre or catching a train

sp8r3N1s6Do0tFL4rzQchg.text: Alright me old sparrow? Alright about sums it up. its Alright, I've had goats brains and eaten a rams nut before. Lock it down with prompt service and you could be nailing it but its all too up in the air, got the wrong nights menu when ordering. I'd like to like you more, but I was left disappointed especially at 16 Queens Pounds for a bowl of ragu.

Oh1qRh_wfoQzFEmI3Ug04A.text: This place is always busy so when a friend suggested dinner there I was intrigued to try it out.  You can't book a table but you can get your name onto the list when you get there and have a drink in the bar whilst you wait. Tables are communal but we got a small table to ourselves which was nicer (although it was a table you'd normally expect for two when there were three of us so it was a bit of a squeeze). The staff were friendly and attentive and it's great that they have a different menu each day so you get really fresh and seasonable ingredients. If you like fish and meat, this is a great place for you! Lots of game and whole fish.  I'm a bit of a fussy eater so I was quite limited on the menu but my friend and boyfriend I was with had plenty to choose from.  If you want a special, get it ordered quickly as I was gutted when the steak had sold out, although I had roast beef which I did enjoy - it was really rare and tender and there was a lot of it.The food was great, but we weren't wowed by it and it was quite pricey, especially for what we had.i probably won't go there again, but I can see why it is popular.

D7_1ym4xwYqrY0TeIXm72Q.text: Stopped in for a quick bite one day last week and really glad I did.Friendly, warm greeting, and there was a free two top and that was mine. Great menu, lots of interesting dishes. Great drinks selection, and quick service.Glad I dropped in, nice experience.Enjoy!

tv-MNGlYFwlienWi0hEBZw.text: Let's say for example that you've never had anchovies and have no idea what it tastes like. You walk into a restaurant that specializes in anchovies and you try it and realize, wow, I really hate anchovies...how do you review this restaurant?I had picked up a London 2011 pamphlet when I first arrived here and Anchor and Hope was on the list of restaurants to eat. The place is ridiculously close to my work so one day for lunch, I suggested we go there. Someone in the group had gone there before and said it was a decent choice so off we went.We sat down, took out the lunch menu, and the Canadian in me was so confused.  I couldnt understand half of the menu and had to ask ppl at our table what they were. The things I did understood included ox heart, rabbit, wood pidgeon, sheep liver pate, and salad. Most of the entrees were at the price of 14 quid.Since it was lunch and I wasn't that hungry or adventurous, I thought the safest thing was to order "crab on toast" (6 pounds) and a side salad (3 pounds). What I got was half a slice of toast with this crab innard tasting pile of goo on top. Two people beside me ordered a grilled kipper, and the wood pidgeon, which looked alright. What was the WORST, however, was their service. Two people in our group ordered salmon salad and one person in the group ordered wild salmon entree. What came instead were three wild salmon entrees. The two people who ordered salad was a bit confused and said they got salad. The server didnt look happy, went back to talk to the person who took our order, who came and claimed it was his mistake and he said if we didnt eat the salmon he'd have to throw it out and that he'd take the salad off of the bill. We kept the salmon and when the bill came, we were charged for all three entree, each of which were TEN QUID MORE than the salad. Perhaps I don't understand what is called "rustic british food" but I'm definitely not coming back here.

dkPzQdo-rFkSiODuxklNgw.text: Great food, but you need to know they run out of things.  You must try the snail salads.  Service is good, and beverages are excellent.  Worth a stop.

2v7SEvuNzWo9xCYa3YJSjg.text: Enter a group of 8, very hungry post-Thorpe Park experience, ready to eat.  A lot.  Magically, The Anchor and Hope had a table for us.  Although a very cramped table, but a table nonetheless!For the positives, I will say that the food is quite good!  All of it is obviously fresh and locally sourced.  Everything is made in house.  I mean EVERYTHING.  So much so that when I asked for mayo for my chips, I was told that no mayo was made that day, and then chided that there is some garlic aioli on my dish anyway (more on the service later).  I had the beetroot salad (delicious!), roasted chopped kid (not so much chopped, but definitely tasty), and the rhubarb queen of puddings (also delicious and the added bonus of a funny name). The downside to this is that menu items do run out.  I had been thinking about the fresh made ice creams the entire evening only to find out they had run out when it was time to order puddings.The quality of the food is somewhat brought down by the kinda crummy service.  At multiple points in the evening, we were greeted with surliness.  Definitely not my favorite emotion in the world of service.  At one point we were told we were taking too long to order and that there were people waiting at the door.  I mentioned above the chiding I got for wanting mayo when there was already aioli on my plate...  Just odd little service related things like that which really got under a lot of our skin.Eh, it was a good experience for the food!  Give it a go... maybe you'll have a better service related experience!

4DGmgAAWi_zGlKaCQ_SnfA.text: I'm gonna give it 4 despite an unfriendly server because overall it would be a favorite if I were local.  We had no issue walking in and getting a table for just my wife and I.  Mismatched furniture helped to give it a cozy atmosphere.  It is a gastropub truly focused on the gastro.  It is simple food, yet creative and contemporary British, which I found to be exactly what I wanted from it.  We were just eating a light lunch(which is why I think they resented our visit), but the watercress and beet salad was quite good.  The lentils were great too, as was the other simple greens we had.  The lady had a nice prosecco and for me, a flurry of pints. To me, gastropubs in the States are more serious about the balance between drinks and the food, but after all they are pubs aren't they?  The world is offering tons of interesting beers, and in my opinion Britain is mostly unaware, despite being a beer drinking culture.  This was a cool, neighborhood spot, casual and serious at the same time and is a nice break from traditional pubs and chain restaurants.

QuVxKtP2E04qK2KpHdeXMQ.text: Quite a few people have commented about the long wait at this gastropub, but realistically, if you're reading the reviews before going to this restaurant, you should know what you're in for! Get there early if you can and prepare to wait a while. You can get a bottle of wine and have some good conversation before taking the bottle to your seat -- even though the place fills in, the wait generally isn't as long as one would assume. Although I have arrived later and was still seated without too much hassle/wait, you will also benefit from arriving early because their menu changes daily, meaning it's fresh, but they will also run out of their most scrumptious items!Once you do sit down, do some exercises to expand your stomach and prepare for a feast of meat or fish. They do also have vegetarian options which are generally great, but this place excels in its huge portions of impeccably cooked meats, ranging from lamb to wood pigeons. You will not leave hungry! If you're with a larger group, the 3-person lamb shoulder is phenomenal, if it's on the menu that day. I have also sampled quite a few of their fish choices, and I have never been disappointed. Highly recommend this spot for people with some time on their hands and in the mood for a huge amount of delicious 'modern European' food in a gastropub setting!

k4qibtUcSEfi-dqzygQBsA.text: Great place. Very relaxed and classy place. Great food. Martini's served in a shot glass. What's not to like.

LbhjeDrlDhI6OZeCA4k0fQ.text: I've now lived in London for almost two years and I'm lucky enough to have this restaurant be down the block from me.  I have yet to have a bad meal there, but the real standouts for me have been the lamb and cassoulet .I love their prossecco cocktails too.  I actually don't mind the communal seating, but wish they took reservations for dinner (sometimes I really crave their food but the wait can be a bit of a deterrent), but it's the kind of place I love to bring people visiting from out of town for good food and a great night out.

T8FeMzeCTh3py7eZuL2iiA.text: Very well known on the gastropub scene and a popular pre-theatre dinner location for the masses, The Anchor and Hope is sometimes known as 'The Wait and Hope' - you'll be very lucky (and patient/early/just two of you) to get a seat in their small dining room for dinner.But if you do, you'll be impressed. You'll struggle to relate their menu to typical pub fayre, and you might even need to ask for a translation (or use your iphone) for some of their offerings. I liked the open kitchen arrangement - you can see for yourself the care going into putting your meal together. It was surprisingly quick too, given it was full.The menu does change daily, but if they have the pork on the list; do yourself a favour. It was delicious. I was heartily jealous of the couple next to me sharing the cassoulet - smelt and looked amazing.Can't say I'll be back in a hurry, as I feel like I've got the t-shirt now, but I'll not grumble if someone invites me there for dinner.

74swAwGv4Tw8BN8r0rEOvQ.text: This review was not based on food as I never got to try any. This is based on service and even understanding how the place worked. In brief: The dining room is completed separated from the bar area. You have to go to the back of the bar and around the corner towards the bathrooms to see the dining room. I could not find a separate door for the dining room so am uncertain if one even exists. The Host/Hostess should be back there somewhere. Read on for my complete disgruntled story.I was seriously confused by this place. I stopped by here after reading reviews hoping my bf and I could just grab a corner or table or something. It was pretty crowded but there were some space on the patio benches outside. Pretty good sign I'd say. I go in, and I can't find a host/hostess. I look around to see what others are doing and they are all going up to the bar. No official line, as most bars, so I squeeze in between some people and wait to get the bartender's attention. After 5 minutes he asks what he can get me so I ask if there's a menu. He asks if I mean a drink or food menu. I ask for both and then clarifies for me that they have a dining room down the hall way and around the corner (where I couldn't really see past). Embarrassed, I apologize for not realizing it and ask if I would still be able to get food at the bar as well. He said he would check. Disappeared for about 5 minute, comes back and says the guy would be over to take my order. We wait some more... Another guy asks what he can get me, I tell him I wanted to order some food, and he points at the first guy I talked to and tells me to give him my order and walks away. Well I wasn't going to try the same guy again so I give up. But the BF keeps trying! (yay)Once we figured out where the dining room was we head back that way down the narrow and cramped hallway. We see a waiter and ask if we can get a table. He points out the host (way in the back) and wait for him to come back toward the entry way. When he finally does we ask how long the wait is and he says at least an hour. So we ask can we get food at the bar too? He answered ask the bartender (and describes the same guy I talked to the first time). We give up hope and leave.

q07DeRmk40p0qhzNDaSyhA.text: If you're looking for some home-style cooking served in a gastro-pubby environment, this is your spot.  You can eat both in their dining room or in the bar.  The staff are super friendly and full of smiles and they really made our visit!  It's a great casual environment for a low key evening out.  I enjoyed the Dover sole which was served with sautéed spinach.  There was a lovely butter sauce and the fish was perfectly cooked.  The rest of the dishes were a bit more hit and miss.  The octopus was tender and my friend loved this but I found it a bit bland. It just lacked any bold flavours.  The crab broth with cheese toasts also lacked depth.  The broth tasted of crab but also had another flavour that I couldn't place which gave it a slightly odd taste - nothing horrible but it just detracted from the crab.  And the broth wasn't hot enough to melt the cheese into a gooey melty stringy mess.  This dish didn't work for me.  The purple sprouting broccoli wasn't purple and was slightly overcooked.  However, I loved the pairing of the anchovy sauce and the toasted almonds.  To be honest, a lot of this could have been circumvented with better presentation.  Everything looked slopped on the plate and reminded me of what you might get at someone's house for dinner, on a weeknight when they did't have time to prepare.  It also came out much too quickly, giving the impression that much of it was not made to order, and the staff weren't good about re-arranging things or taking things away to free up space.  Overall, a decent meal.  But the food was slightly disappointing.

y91Nh3QfpupE_a47QmQCUQ.text: Crazy busy but good service. yZ-pzBTCI3PgMGNSqXpilA.text: A unimpressive exterior. It just looks like another random pub along The Cut. I've walked passed it for several years and never bothered to enter.
